verbs.description: entrench (third-person singular simple present entrenches, present participle entrenching, simple past and past participle entrenched) (transitive, intransitive)

entries.meaning: (construction, archaeology) To dig or excavate a trench; to trench.
(military) To surround or provide with a trench, especially for defense; to dig in.
examples: The army entrenched its camp, or entrenched itself.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) To establish a substantial position in business, politics, etc.
examples: Senator Cornpone was able to entrench by spending millions on each campaign.

entries.meaning: To invade; to encroach; to infringe or trespass; to enter on, and take possession of, that which belongs to another; usually followed by on or upon.
To cut in; to furrow; to make trenches in or upon.
(figuratively) To become completely absorbed in and fully accept one's beliefs, even in the face of evidence against it and refusing to be reasoned with.
